title: 107_s524
content: The Act titled "Small Business Interest Checking Act of 2001" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. Public Law 93-100 (12 U.S.C. 1832) is amended to allow depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. This amendment does not affect the status of the account as a transaction account. The amendment to Public Law 93-100 allows account holders to make up to 24 transfers per month within the same institution without affecting the account's status as a transaction account. SEC. 3. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on the payment and distribution of these earnings. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The distribution of earnings to depository institutions and their responsibilities, along with authorization for pass-through reserves for member banks, are outlined in the amendment. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances at a Federal Reserve bank. Authorization for pass-through reserves for member banks is also included in the amendment. SEC. 4. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements, allowing for a ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 5. Federal Reserve surpluses can be transferred. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2001 through 2005. During fiscal years 2002 through 2006, the Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each reserve bank must pay annually. No reserve bank can replenish its surplus fund with transferred amounts during this period. During fiscal years 2002 through 2006, any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of member banks in a Federal Reserve bank will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
